There are a number of ways poverty can lead to crime. Of course not everyone who is struggling with poverty commits criminal acts and many who end up in the judicial system are guilty of being poor rather than actually being criminals. First, the obvious. If a person is living in poverty they are less likely to have access to advanced education, life skills and job training. They are more likely to face unemployment or under employment. They are more likely to live in areas where crimes such as gangs and substance abuse are prevalent. Growing up in such environments increase the possibility of becoming involved in such activities because of the despair, frustration, anger and hopelessness created in such environments. If faced with the choice of barely getting by on a minimum wage job or making good money dealing drugs, many choose the criminal life because it allows an escape from poverty. So, for these reasons poverty may lead to more criminal activity. Second, a person struggling every day with the deprivations of poverty might resort to criminal behavior out of seeming necessity. If your children are hungry and you have no money for food you are more inclined towards stealing to feed your family. If you can't pay rent you may feel the only way to avoid homelessness is to get money through illegal activities. Third is perhaps the most problematic way in which poverty can lead to a person being treated as a criminal. Let's say a person living in poverty gets pulled over for speeding and gets a ticket. A financially stable person can simply pay the ticket and move on but a very poor person doesn't have the extra hundred dollars or so. So the person goes to court to ask for leniency or permission to pay the ticket over time. Automatically court costs are added that can be $50-80 or more in some places. The judge agrees that you can pay over say 6 months. But now the $100 ticket is $150. The judge says you must be on probation until the ticket is paid. In many places that means you must pay a fee to the probation department until you have paid off the ticket. And they add an administrative fee for allowing you to pay over time. Now your $100 ticket is $175 with all the court cost. So probation says you must pay $30 per month on the ticket and $25 for probation. So now each month you must pay $55. Now, for many people paying a $55 a month bill might be irritating but wouldn't pose a serious financial hardship. But when you are already struggling to pay rent and buy food $55 might be nearly impossible. So, a couple months in you miss a payment. You simply don't have $55. Now probation is threatening to tell the courts you are in contempt and you could face more serious problems. Next month you have to pay $110 but you just don't have it. So the courts suspended your driver's license but you have to get to work otherwise you will never be able to pay it off. Then you get caught driving on a suspended license. Next stop is jail. Then comes having to post bail and you are back in court. Now the judge is angry but willing to give you another chance. But you end up with another fine and court costs and it is back to probation. But you have lost your job because you didn't show up and didn't call because you were in jail. But it doesn't matter because your car was towed when you were arrested and in order to get it back you have to pay the towing fee of about $125 plus a $50 a day storage fee. Now that $100 ticket you got is going to cost you more than $500 when it is all over. And you are now locked in to the criminal justice system. And it becomes an overwhelming cycle that seems sometimes as if it is forcing a person into crime.

No. Poverty does not promote or create crime, and certainly not on it's own many factors must be considered. I hear those nay Sayers saying "show me the evidence, you're insane"… Well there was actually an experiment in New York, Baltimore, Los Angeles, Boston and Chicago where this was tested in some measure. In Moving to Opportunity, 5,000 families were subsidised to move from poor to affluent areas. The results were somewhat surprising. Ten years on, the boys in those families were 20 per cent more likely to have been excluded from school than those who stayed behind. They were also more likely to have been arrested, though interestingly they were less likely to have been arrested for violent crime. In this case, moving poor kids to rich areas didn't make them less likely to be criminals, but it did change the type of crime they were likely to commit… So this leads to many conclusions, as it would appear that "poverty" alone wasn't the only factor contributing to "crime" only defining the type of crime most common.. So Not having enough money isn't the thing I see causing crime. I would imagine Pain, trauma and neglect in childhood are more influential factors. But then location is also a factor, Violent crime, for example, peaks on pay day when people go out spending cash on drink and get into fights. Perhaps this could be reduced by daily payments, instead of big amounts all at once.. Where there are high-rises you get less burglary but more violent crime, whereas in the suburbs you get more burglary. But the strange and complicated thing is that each and every human is unique, and may act differently in certain situations. Moving to Opportunity - Wikipedia

There’s some nuance to this. A person may be relatively impoverished and get involved in drug dealing using the rationalization that they’re just ‘helping people have a good time’ and getting paid for it, even if the person would never resort to violence or theft to make money. And then that person may run into some more dangerous, shady characters accusing them of infringing on their ‘turf’, and find themselves crossing that particular moral event horizon and resorting to violence to deal with them. Another example of nuance in how poverty can lead to crime is that a relatively impoverished person may do expensive things to self-medicate, some of which may be illegal and other things that are legal, things like alcohol abuse, drug abuse, or they may gamble with hopes of winning big and getting out of poverty. They go broke, and then they find themselves desperate enough to resort to serious crime to be able to pay rent, eat, and maintain their addiction. These effects accumulate and people in the poor neighborhood notice the crime and have to live with that going on around them on a daily basis. This can lead to criminality becoming normalized or even seen as ‘cool’. Teenagers start forming gangs. People see legitimate success as elusive, blame the surrounding society for having abandoned them, and so see criminality as a natural, normal reaction to the state of things. But policies need to consider how to give those with lower incomes legitimate opportunities. Punishing failing schools by taking away funding does not work. Giving well-qualified and experienced teachers bonuses for teaching in struggling school districts would help. Universities should also offer affirmative action for people who come from neighborhoods whose school systems are struggling, not based on race, but based on geography. Reward the students who in spite of it all do well in these schools and it will show people in these places that if you work hard you can have legitimate success. For example, children who lived in the neighborhood before gentrification show higher test scores and less behavioral problems and less incidents of delinquency. The negative effects can be alleviated with the right policies such as requiring that landlords not to raise rates too quickly for people who were previously renting. Ultimately having mixed-income neighborhoods is healthier as then the rich and poor are neighbors. Strain theory, social control theory, and differential association theory are widely held theories of criminal behavior causation.
